text: a few decades ago if a spy agency wanted
to track you they would attach a set of
clips to your phone line and listen in
but today's digital communications have
changed everything as you can see here
20 years ago most of the world was
offline but today's networks cover
virtually the entire planet and they're
still growing spy still want to listen
in but there's so much more for them to
sift through rather than tapping one
phone line spies need to exploit a vast
universe of data sending one email from
the BBC in London over to Brazil will
see your message hop through a series of
network points these hubs and cables
link the internet making them prime
targets for spies we've learnt from the
Snowden documents that America and
Britain target every step along which
communications flow they tap fiber-optic
cables a program called tempora the
prism program requests data from
companies like Google Facebook and
Microsoft but they also hacked their way
into those companies internal
connections gaining backdoor access to
people's data they also try to weaken
and break encryption used to keep
messages secret they also track millions
of phones and scan text messages for
information the NSA says it tracks
legitimate national security targets
like terrorists but privacy advocates
say they've gone too far it sparked a
real debate in America where President
Obama has proposed some reforms in an
ever more connected world where our cars
fridges and home heating systems are all
online spies and tech firms will know
more more about us and so the challenges
in trying to balance national security
with privacy will only grow
